intro.heading: FD Calculator Introduction — How to Estimate Your Fixed Deposit Maturity in India
paragraphs: A smart saver uses an FD Calculator for Fixed Deposit maturity to turn a locked-in bank deposit into clear, reliable numbers.
Fixed deposits (FDs) are lump-sum term investments that promise a fixed interest rate for a preset tenure — from as short as 7 days up to 10 years or more.
An FD Calculator instantly converts your principal, tenure and interest rate into the maturity amount and total interest earned, removing manual guesswork.
It also helps you compare simple-interest vs compound-interest FDs, test different compounding frequencies (annual, quarterly, monthly), and see how senior-citizen or special rates change outcomes.
Use the calculator before you invest to choose the best bank/NBFC offering and to plan cash flows precisely at maturity.

whatIsFDSection.heading: What is Fixed Deposit? — FD Calculator Context: Understanding Fixed Deposit Basics
paragraphs: A Fixed Deposit (FD) is a conservative, low-risk saving product offered by banks and NBFCs where you deposit a sum for a fixed period in exchange for a guaranteed rate of interest.
Unlike savings accounts, FD interest rates are higher because funds are locked for the tenure you choose; early withdrawal typically incurs a penalty.

FDs can be simple-interest (interest paid but not compounded) or compound-interest (interest reinvests and itself earns interest), and they may offer special categories — senior citizen FD, tax-saving FD, flexi-FD, and sweep-in FD.
Interest compounding frequency (annual, semiannual, quarterly, monthly) influences returns: more frequent compounding usually yields a higher maturity amount.
Use an FD Calculator to understand how principal, rate, tenure and compounding combine to produce the final payout so you can pick the right FD type for your financial goal.

fdFormulaSection.heading: Calculation formula (simple explanation) — FD Formulas Users Must Understand
fdFormulaSection.intro: FD math uses two core formulas:

formulas.title: Simple interest FD:
formulas.explanation: M = maturity amount, P = principal, r = annual rate (%), t = tenure in years.

formulas.title: Compound interest FD (general compounding):
steps: Periodic rate: r_period = r / (100 × n) where n = compounding periods per year.
Number of periods: m = n × t.
M = P × (1 + r_period)^m.

fdFormulaSection.conclusion: These formulas model how interest either stays separate (simple) or compounds (compound), and how compounding frequency increases effective returns.

seniorRatesSection.heading: Senior citizens & special FD rates — How to Model Senior Citizen and Promotional Rates
seniorRatesSection.intro: Senior citizens often receive extra interest (a small boost over the base rate). Use the steps below to model this in the FD Calculator:
steps: Identify base rate r_base for the FD and the advertised senior boost Δr.
Set r = r_base + Δr in the FD Calculator.
Run the compound formula M = P × (1 + r/n)^(n×t) to see the new maturity.

example.title: Example
example.body: If base rate = 7.0% and senior boost = 0.5%, then r = 7.5%. For P = ₹200,000, t = 3 years and annual compounding: compute (1.075)^3 and multiply by ₹200,000 to get M. The calculator can instantly compare base vs senior scenarios so retirees choose the highest effective return.

seniorRatesSection.conclusion: Use the calculator to compare the base-rate scenario and the senior-rate scenario to see the incremental benefit — often a small rate boost compounds into a meaningful difference over multi-year tenures.

withdrawalsPrematureTaxSection.heading: Withdrawals, premature closure and tax implications — FD Calculator Assumptions & Adjustments
withdrawalsPrematureTaxSection.intro: When modeling FDs, include realistic exit events and tax effects so projections match likely outcomes:
points: Premature closure penalty: many banks deduct a penalty (e.g., 0.5%–1.0% off rate) or pay no interest for the initial period. In the calculator, reduce r or subtract penalty to model early exit.
Partial withdrawals / breakable FDs: some flexi FDs allow withdrawals; adjust principal schedule and recompute remaining compounding.

Taxation: interest from FDs is taxable as per your income slab; TDS may apply above thresholds. The FD Calculator can show gross interest; to estimate post-tax return, apply your marginal tax rate to Interest = M − P.

example.title: Example adjustment (after-tax)
example.body: If gross interest = ₹50,000 and marginal tax = 30%, after-tax interest ≈ ₹35,000 (50,000 × (1 − 0.30)). For premature closure, if penalty = 0.75% on rate, reduce r by 0.75 percentage points when computing M.

withdrawalsPrematureTaxSection.note: Always check current bank penalty rules and tax regulations. The calculator provides projections and not tax advice.
withdrawalsPrematureTaxSection.conclusion: Model withdrawals, penalties and taxes explicitly in the inputs to produce realistic maturity and after-tax return figures.
